title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: A brief comment on this post:  I realize that some may find the idea itself a little ludicrous, perhaps even insulting.  I, myself, have never seriously thought it might be ape or monkey blood.  Then, why go there?  Because I think it’s important to critically analyze the data from as many different scientific disciplines as possible.  This analysis is from the perspective of immunology, in which specificity is the cornerstone.  The issue is isolated to examine “What does the data really tell us about the species origin of the blood?”
author: Kelly Kearse

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: What are we to think about the observation reported by Lucotte (“Vérités sur le Saint Suaire”, p.147 ff) on erythrocytes found on the Shroud (microscopic material collected by Giovanni Riggi di Numana) with diameters of 12.5-13 micrometer – much too large a value for human blood, according to this author.
author: Jos Verhulst

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: Some might argue that red blood cell membranes may reseal/fuse during the fixation procedure using for microscopic preparation; also, I believe the same author might have also reported that certain mineral particles may mimic the appearance of red blood cells.  I think it would important to verify microscopic (visual) identification of red blood cells with some biochemical data, using microscopy together with (gold-conjugaed) antibodies directed against specific membrane markers, for example, to ensure that you are really looking at (reconstituted) red blood cells in the field.  Baima Bollone has published a picture of what appear to be red blood cells on Shroud fibers in several of his books, but also includes a photograph of a silica particle in an adjacent panel to illustrate the similarities.
author: Kelly Kearse

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: Gérard Lucotte claims to have observed, in the micro debris aspired from the Shroud, 9 smaller erythrocytes that could be of primate/human origin (“Il s’agit sûrement d’hématies humaines” – p.150), and 55 larger ones that are not of primate origin (“elles proviennent probablement d’un grand mammifère domestique” p.179). His book also has some pictures of these red blood cells (p.273-276). Possibly this work is flawed but these claims should be addressed.
author: Jos Verhulst

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: Besides, one should be here reminded most if not all the archaeological bloodstains on the Turin Sindon have a colour between carmine brown and carmine red and look as if ‘fresh’. MOST LIKELY they are ‘fresh-looking’ re-dried aged re-moistened dried bloodstains strongly suggesting the burial sheet was first moistened or in-soaked with aqueous alkaline solution (e.g. ashes, Jerusalem limestone dust  and/or urea residues mixed with pure living water/collected rainwater). Note:  Jerusalem limestone dust mixed with water can gelatinized starch. Then the moistened/in-soaked burial cloth could have been subjected to a low temperature accidental/providential thermal imprinting process (e.g. ritual fumigation and/or corpse hyperthermia).
author: Max Patrick Hamon

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: Yes. See e.g. Brizzi V., Brizzi A., 2012: About Iceman’ Arrowhead: “Blood residue was visible in the area between the surface of the (arrow)point and the inner surface of the hafting wood. A single Hemastix test was made which returned a reaction of 1+. The surface was very hydrophobic and comparisons made before and after the test indicate that very likely residue was actually removed and tested. When removing residue from the basal thick deposits (Sample #24) more liquid was used and a longer soaking time was allowed. The subsequent liquid sample was viscous and reddish brown, consistent with experience removing thick blood residues from other archaeological tools (for example see Loy 1993)”.
author: Max Patrick Hamon

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post: Hugh, why don’t you try just to mix fresh human oxygenated/non oxygenated blood with an aqueous alkaline solution, moisten or soak a piece of linen in it and have the moistened/soaked cloth dry out via low temperature fumigation and see what happens?

title: Guest Posting by Kelly Kearse:  Distinguishing human blood from that of other species
post:
I believe Ian Wilson mentioned in one of his books that Thomas Loy had told him he had seen a similarly colored blood on prehistoric artifacts-I believe that was in a conversation, don’t recall a specific reference for it.  I looked for contact information for Dr. Loy last year on the internet and learned he was deceased.
Perhaps someone else has run across other examples?  Would be interesting to research into older artifacts and see if this ever comes up, and if so, under what conditions

Exactly. plus an addition of blood to other bodily fluid will stain and stay in a different way than whole human blood. The whole human blood staine when washed just with a plain, but hot water, will change the color of remains and actually permanently fix the cloth . If water has any contamination ( which any water except distilled will have) possible reactions between the contaminants and blood and plasma components are endless.
